abstract: Bank of America had argued that the law restricting a bank to no more than 10 percent of the nation’s deposits is “antiquated” and anticompetitive.
snippet: Bank of America had argued that the law restricting a bank to no more than 10 percent of the nation’s deposits is “antiquated” and anticompetitive.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America’s chairman and chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis, said yesterday that the company was backing away from a quiet lobbying effort to change a federal law that could prevent it from making major acquisitions.

headline.main: Big Bank Stops Effort to Change Law Limiting Growth
headline.print_headline: Big Bank Stops Effort to Change Law Limiting Growth

abstract: Bank of America‘s chairman and chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis, said Tuesday that the company was backing away from a quiet lobbying effort to change a federal law that could prevent it from making major acquisitions. Just weeks after agreeing to initiate discussions with lawmakers to raise the possibility of lifting the 10 percent federal deposit cap, Kenneth D. Lewis told The New York Times that he had told bank representatives to “back off” from those plans.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America‘s chairman and chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis, said Tuesday that the company was backing away from a quiet lobbying effort to change a federal law that could prevent it from making major acquisitions. Just weeks after agreeing to initiate discussions with lawmakers to raise the possibility of lifting the 10 percent federal deposit cap, Kenneth D. Lewis told The New York Times that he had told bank representatives to “back off” from those plans.

headline.main: Bank of America Tones Down Deposit Cap Stance
